@duggalsf  I just had a look at your page. Looking on mobile I think that in story section you don’t need two container-fluid classes. It eats the precious space. If you leave one container-fluid div and add col-xs-12 to the div that currently has col-md-8 class + you add class=“img-responsive” to your photo everything looks much better. I know you did not ask about this, but I think it can be also helpful :) I’d also make social buttons bigger on mobile. There are four of them so I’d suggest going to putting them in a separate row one next to other with some padding. I’d also make them aa bit bigger, for tappability reasons. You may also have a look at the logos above, they do not fit in the mobile screen now. You may play here with a row and columns, similarly to social buttons. I like minimalism in your design :)

http://materializecss.com/footer.html#sticky-footer

@bomholt To fix your footer, use Materialize's sticky footer by wrapping everything but your footer in  <main></main> and adding this css:
```css
body
  display: flex
  min-height: 100vh
  flex-direction: column

main
  flex: 1 0 auto
```

If you say, I want a margin of "5%" of the screen, every screen has room for 5% margin
It "hard-codes" your design.  For example, by using a margin of 1050px, the code is saying "I don't want to respond to any screen smaller than 1050 pixels"

If you want responsive, avoid pixels where possible, use percentages for as many measurements as possible

@davidamidon Hi. Sorry for the wait. I forgot I had to pick up my dog from the groomer so had to rush out. Unfortunately it seems like you've picked a bad api. it is throwing a "No 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' header is present on the requested resource." error and with fairly poor documentation it's hard to tell how you'd get around it. on the HTML: I think there are way too many `div` tags.
- why wrapping every heading tag in a div? The h tag will add line breaks for you and content-wise heading implies title?
- in the reproduction section,  the mating/gestation part seems fit for a table/list instead of paragraphs.

on the CSS
- When reading from a screen, it usually helps to use a sans-serif font.
- add some padding to those paragraphs to have a gap between the border and your paragraph text.

@jilldebiase inline styles mostly for learning  styling. Don't use them in actual projects. Assign classes to page elements which you'll need to group for applying styles to multiple elements at once. Lastly, any time you target a single element, assign an ID.

@NPeyralans you simply return anything from JS function with return,
 In this weather app you cannot do that, because: 
you send request to ip-api and set function on $ajax.success to wait for response
your program go on with code 
when response later arrive JS call and execute that function and you can only handle the response within that func
- you can only send next request to weather app with data returned from ip-api form that function 
that next $ajax request will also have its own $ajax.success function, for handling response form weatherapi
Hope this help

```
<head>

  <script src="http://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.6/js/bootstrap.min.js"></script>
</head>
```

@sirens your HTML starts with a closing `</html>`tag, and you have several nested `container-fluid` classes. For the text resizing issue, you are giving different CSS properties to `#name` and `#quote`. If you give them both the same CSS properties, they will behave the same. Delete your `#name` in your CSS and change `#quote` to `#quote`,  `#name` to see what I mean.

@sammie-r7 It's called hotlinking when you link to another website's image file in your code. Some people don't like others doing that, so they block it. Also, the pictures aren't under your control, so they can disappear without notice. It's best to save the picture you want and upload it somewhere like github, photobucket, flickr, postimage.org, etc..

Bill Nye

The man who inspired a generation to love science

Bill Nye, The Science Guy

Here's a time line of Bill Nye's life:

  • 1955 - Born in Washington, D.C. to Jacqueline and Edwin Nye.
  • 1973 - Graduated Sidwell Friends Private School.
  • 1977 - Graduated B.S. in Mechanical Engineering at Cornell University.
  • 1991-1993 - Appeared in the Back to the Future: The animated Series as assistant to Dr. Emmett Brown (Christopher Loyd).
  • 1993-1998 - Hosted Bill Nye the Science Guy, aiming to teach specific science topics to young audiences.
  • 2000-2002 - Technical expert in BattleBots
  • 2004 and 2005 - Hosted 100 Greatest Discoveries for the Science Channel.
  • 2008 -Hosted Stuff Happens.
  • 2009 -Recorded a YouTube video advocating clean-energy legislation on behalf of Al Gore's campaign.
  • 2012 - Went against the religious establishment by claiming that creationist views threaten science education and innovation in the United States.
  • 2014 - Published "Undeniable: Evloution and the Science of Creation"
  • 2014 - Was a celebrity guest and interviewer at the White House Student Film Festival.
  • 2015 - Met with U.S. President Obama to visit the Everglades National Park to discuss climate change as well as science education.

Hi @sok213:
* either angular or react is more about a personal choice... I am doing angular because I studied a lot of mean before they decided to support react... I feel more confident with angular now... in my case, I am selecting what I feel more confident with... if you are new, consider if you want to learn one or another and try to work on what you feel more confident with... the gap between what you have done so far and basejumps is huge anyway, so you will be facing problem with any of them at the beginning... currently everyone is trying react so the angular help is not more, but you can find problems and solutions by doing a gitter search at the room... I have been studying react too and found that for full stack angular has more references online... in principle, you can do what other people advise: don't focus on whether react is better than angular or viceversa: both do a good job for many things, so try to learn at least one but learn it *right*.
* I have been using infinite of resources, the majority not in FCC I am afraid... books, courses, etc... This is a problem that FCC is still to resolve: no good in-house tutorials for basejumps... I preferred angular-fullstack instead of clementine because I believe it is more job related, but it is a bit opinionated too... but clementine is the supported tool and the tool developer is very active in the helpbasejumps room.
* I am building from my computer - asking to use c9.io is for those who need linux terminals and some pre-installed libraries. It is also good if you want to share your work with someone. But the angular-fullstack generator showed to be too big for the available memory of c9.io free plans. clementine is smaller and c9.io can be used... you always can use c9.io for Angular and for React, but currently the setup it is harder for the second.

Go to the basejumps room and ask! Good luck!
Did you build everything on c9.io?
What kinds of resources do you recommend going through before starting a fullastack application?

@evaristoc Thanks for the info, so in your opinion, for someone who is still very new at building Full Stack applications, should I stick with Angular for now to build all the basejumps? Since yeoman does not support react anyways?

@sok213, @Manolo-S, @samosale  hi: I am working basejumps, came to FCC with no experience in web-dev whatsoever but some training with backend... I tried at first the voteplex project and it didn't work for me at all... I had to go back to basis and learn more MEAN before really starting... today I finished my first project after doing a pair of "projects over the counter", the last one a [re-indexed reference of some ziplines at codepen](https://ziplinesfcc.herokuapp.com/pen), using scraping techniques.

Advice? Start with those with the less requirements.

FCC doesn't mention that (which I believe it is a bit misleading) but in my opinion there is a way to build up the experience required for the voteplex project (the most difficult one) if you go in an order similar to this one:
1. stockmarket
2. nightlife
3. pintirest
4. book trading
5. voteplex

I have been building up experience with angular-fullstack generator. From what I have seen so far react is proving hard to implement with the current knowledge base, which has been growing mostly around MEAN, and some people end up doing jQuery. clementine.js is still focused a bit on MEAN, although a bit agnostic and boilerplate... No idea of a existing generator using react: sort of MERN...

@samosale I haven't looked into yeoman, yet. Perhaps there are alternatives that do use React? I want to work through the clementine tutorials first to get a better notion of what full-stack development is. All I know is that React will have to fit in with whatever I'm going to do.

@sok213 FCC is planning on using React in stead of Angular in their curriculum because they think it's better. So, yes. I read that Angular can be more broadly used than React but that's as much as I know right now.

@kpaccess @jedpimentel that is right. It would be best to take the number and decimal input as a string. Then parse it as a float and store to a variable when you select an operator or equals

@kpaccess when the calculator is expecting a "number" input, you cold start with an empty string, then have each number-key press append that num-character to the end of it. That way if you type 7-5-1 it'll have "751". I think one way would be to create that empty string whenever a num-key is first pressed, and keep appending while numbers are still being pressed. (and have it operated on, or saved, or whatever, when a non-num key is pressed). The period would be part of the group (though it should only appear once in the string). I think @meecoder @ThiagoFerreir4 are already there, but I wanted to give the the formal project description ;)

Hi everyone, we have a requested application. It’s not for a nonprofit - it’s for us to use internally. It will be challenging, but could be built in stages, by several campers or pairs of campers.

The users
Free Code Camp’s nonprofit project team and Twitch Live Code team.

The Problem
We frequently need to schedule meetings with campers and nonprofit stakeholders. These people are located all around the world in different time zones. We need to figure out each person’s availability so we can find an optimal time to meet.

The Current Solution
We use a tool called WorldTimeBuddy.com to look at times across time zones.
We use a tool called when2meet.com to figure out which times work best for all participants.
But when2meet doesn’t localize to the individual users' timezones.
So we need a tool that combines these functionalities.

This tool could go on to become a major open source project, and would look excellent in your portfolio. If you’re interested in building this, PM me. Thanks!

#The Current Solution#
We use a tool called WorldTimeBuddy.com to look at times across time zones. 
We use a tool called when2meet.com to figure out which times work best for all participants.
But when2meet doesn’t localize to the individual users' timezones.
So we need a tool that combines these functionalities.

This tool could go on to become a major open source project, and would look excellent in your portfolio. If you’re interested in building this, PM me. Thanks!

@duttakapil Awesome idea bro...it'd be awesome if it was part of our curriculum

We are thinking of making this project idea a part of the FCC Curriculum. The Projects challenge will consist of three parts. 
* Build your own personal website. 
* Join a team and build a website for your team. 
* Build a project website with your team. 

We guys, i.e. FCC Web Crafts, are the first team of FCC to initiate this idea.  And since we have already (almost) build a website for our team, and some of us have our portfolio site setup, the only thing left to do is building a web project with the team. 
The idea is, since the future students will have to join a team, probably consisting 5 members, and build a project, why don't we create a Project Generator website for them? We will gather as many project ideas as we can and put it in the database, and then the future FCC students can visit the website, click on the button "Generate Random Project" or something, and a project will be selected for them randomly from the database. That will be our web project, and we can put in some additional stuff if we want. This way, by the end, not only will we have 1000 hours of coding experience and working with non-profits, but also a ready portfolio website, the experience of working in a team and learning how to take a project idea and turn it into reality. All this will be useful for our future Web Developer work, and it will also strengthen the skills we have learned at FCC.

Here are some possible practical steps to get you started on your very own Camper Practice Project:

Step 1) Make a Camper Practice Project forum post explaining your project idea and vision.

Step 2)Give you project a name. You probably want to name it after something that gives other Free Code Campers a general idea of what your project is about.

Step 3) Start recruiting people to join in and be a part of your Camper Practice Project, either in this forum or through the chat: https://gitter.im/FreeCodeCamp/CamperPracticeProjects

Step 4)Once other campers offer to join your Camper Practice Project, you might want appoint a front-end project manager and a back-end project manager for your project, that is, if you have something more intricate in mind. 
Splinting your Camper Practice Project in 2 sections will make it easier to for you and your team to better manage the project development and all the details concerning it. Of course if your project is either front-end or back-end you might not need to split in 2.

Step 5)Once the Camper Practice Project core team members are found, start making arrangements as a team to get your project started in the right track.

Step 6) And last but not least, let your Camper Practice Project begin and happy coding!

PS: Please feel free to point out any other possible practical steps for your Camper Practice Project.

I have a lot of amazing ideas for the projects, but I thought of something even better. Ok so this is kind of a elaborate idea, so bear with me. The idea is of creating just three web projects. The first one will be your own personal website. The second one will be a website for your team, like FCC Web Crafts, and the third one will be a team project you decide with your team. This idea of building projects is really great and it should officially become a part of the FCC curriculum. So I was thinking that if we do make it a part of the FCC curriculum then there will a lot of students in the future who would want to make their own teams and build a project like we are trying to do right now. Think of FCC Web Crafts as the first team to initiate this idea. What we do is build a website with a simple purpose, a project generator. We will think about and gather as many project ideas we can and put them on the site and then the future students could make their own teams like FCC Web Crafts, which probably will have mostly 5 members with one member being a experienced coder and the mentor for the team and then they can use our website to randomly generate a project idea. They then will try to work together to build that project as a team and submit it and move on with the FCC Challenges to the bonfires and non profits. This will help us and the future students to put all the skills that we learned in Js, HTML and CSS to test.  This challenge could come right after they complete the GitHub course, because the teams would probably want to collaborate on GitHub. This way, every FCC student will by the end have a portfolio website, the experience of working in a team, which will be helpful in a web developer job post, and learning how you take a project idea and make it real. This would serve as a bonus on doing 1000 hours of code and working with non-profits, it will strengthen out skills.  So what do you guys think?
